awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Washington (UW) proposes an extension for the Alliance for Access to Computing Careers (AccessComputing).  AccessComputing is the cornerstone of the national effort to broaden the participation of persons and students with disabilities in computing.  Through an array of institutional partnerships and research on universal design for inclusion of students with disabilities, AccessComputing is directly aligned with NSF goals of broadening participation.  AccessComputing focuses on students with disabilities who are a critically underserved group in STEM fields.

AccessComputing engages individuals with disabilities as well as those who support, serve, guide, educate, and employ them in transformational efforts to make the computing disciplines more welcoming and accessible to individuals with disabilities, including post-9/11 veterans. AccessComputing is a combined effort of UW's Department of Computer Science and Engineering and DO-IT (Disabilities, Opportunities, Internetworking, and Technology) Center, in partnership with diverse set of postsecondary institutions, Broadening Participation in Computing (BPC) Alliances, and computing organizations. The Alliance aims to (1) increase the capacity of postsecondary institutions, precollege educators, BPC Alliances, and industry to fully include individuals with disabilities in computing fields; (2) provide direct services to individuals using evidence-based practices that support those individuals as they move through critical junctures on the way to computing careers; (3) build synergistic and lasting relationships among stakeholders to promote systemic changes toward inclusiveness in computing education and careers; and (4) expand an online resource center to share research and successful practices worldwide. Applying methods grounded in knowledge management, collaboration, and social network theory and practice, this extension to the AccessComputing award will formalize earlier and new relationships into a multitier organizational structure of partners, collaborators, and affiliates. Outcomes for individuals with disabilities will be documented by tracking the progress of student participants as well as institutional enrollment and graduation data; and results will be compared to local, regional, and national data with respect to the academic and career success of people with disabilities.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The University of Washington (UW) received NSF funding to increase the scope, outcomes, impact, and sustainability of the Alliance for Access to Computing Careers (AccessComputing) Second Extension (AccessComputing3). The goal of the AccessComputing Third Extension (AccessComputing4) was to increase the number of people with disabilities successful in degree completion and careers in computing fields. The following summarizes outputs and outcomes from the AccessComputing Third Extension project.

Outputs and Outcomes for Students with Disabilities: During the project, 1,179 individuals with disabilities participated in college transition and bridge academies, workshops, presentations, an online mentoring community, internships, conference attendance, and/or other opportunities offered through AccessComputing. Students interested in receiving comprehensive support and ongoing engagement in the AccessComputing initiative joined the AccessComputing Team.

During the project period, 629 students with disabilities joined the AccessComputing Team. They received peer and mentor support within an e-mentoring community; secured internships; engaged in college and career transition events; received tutoring; attended conferences; and/or received advice from project staff and other participants regarding the acquisition of assistive technology and preparation for computing studies and careers.

A total of 621 (98.7%) of the 629 AccessComputing Team members were enrolled in postsecondary education during the project. Thirty-seven participants pursued a two-year degree or a certificate. Of these, 1 was still attending at the time of data collection and 26 (70.2%) had graduated. Of those who had graduated, 9 (34.6%) transitioned into a four-year program. Of the 458 enrolled in a four-year degree program, 369 (80.6%) graduated during the data collection period and 49 (10.7%) were still attending. Of the 369 who had graduated 78  (21.1%) transitioned into a graduate or professional program during the data collection period. Of the 213 who had enrolled in a graduate or professional program during the data collection period, 98 (46.0%) graduated from a masters program (8 of whom (8.2%) continued on to a PhD program),  40 (18.8%) graduated from a PhD program, and 75 (35.2%) were still attending.

One of the strategies employed by AccessComputing was to provide diverse learning experiences and to support team members’ interest in computing is engagement in internships. Students participated in 349 internships and 49 Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REUs). The REUS were conducted at different universities nationwide. During the data collection period 345 of the AccessComputing Team members secured employment, 321 (93.0%) computer-related.

Organizational Capacity Development and Alliance Impact. AccessComputing worked to foster synergistic and lasting relationships among stakeholders to promote systemic changes toward inclusiveness and to increase the capacity of postsecondary institutions, organizations that broaden participation in computing, and industry to fully include individuals with disabilities in computing fields and promote accessible design practices. Project outputs and outcomes include:

Partner Engagement. AccessComputing engaged with 58 academic partners, 8 industry partners, 17 organizational partners, and 349 collaborators. Partners regularly communicated via online meetings, online communities of practice, and led project activities within their organizations.  

Communities of Practice (CoP). A total of 923 individuals participated in four CoPs to discuss issues and share resources related to the project goal.

Training. 53 web-based trainings, reached 3,635 individuals and 8 CBIs that involved a total of 372 individuals. Additionally, 4,957 individuals participated in events at partner and collaborator sites and 7,408 individuals received training through 134 presentations at regional and national conferences and meetings.

Dissemination. AccessComputing created a website, 18 journal articles; 6 conference papers; 2 white papers; 2 book chapters; 3 blog posts; 3 brochures; 2 flyers; 1 book; 17 program newsletters; 5 CBI proceedings and 5 videos. More than 8,617 copies of project materials were freely distributed.

Collaborations to Increase Accessibility. AccessComputing collaborated with

Broadening Participation of Computing Alliances, computing organizations, conferences, and departments to increase the accessibility of their organizations, all of which engage with people with disabilities.

The AccessComputing ensured long-term impact because it:

  • broaden the participation of people with disabilities - including those who are also women, underrepresented minorities, veterans, and/or economically disadvantaged - in computing fields;
  • build on existing associations and networks and create durable relationships among stakeholders in an integrated effort that enhances the infrastructure for research and education;
  • publish transformational research and practices to enhance understanding and promote replication; and
  • put into place structures that will sustain project impact after the project funding period has ended.

Transformational project outcomes benefit society by making computing opportunities available to more citizens and by enhancing computing fields with the talents and perspectives of people with disabilities. Project products are available on the project website at http://www.washington.edu/accesscomputing/.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2023
Modified by: Sheryl Burgstahler
